## Temperature

Overall temperature data appears to be bimodally distributed. This is expected and confirmed to be due to seasonality (see the final seasons histogram). 
```{r}


temp_hist <- na_data %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Temp_C))+
  geom_histogram()
temp_hist

#severe outlier in temperature histogram - going to remove and remake data
#ROW 793

na_data <- na_data[-c(793),]

temp_hist <- na_data %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Temp_C))+
  geom_histogram()
temp_hist

#bimodal plot, going to look at different seasons
unique(na_data$Season)

#Spring temperature histogram
temp_hist_spr <- na_data %>% 
  filter(Season == "Spring") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Temp_C))+
  geom_histogram()
temp_hist_spr

#Summer temperature histogram
temp_hist_sum <- na_data %>% 
  filter(Season == "Summer") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Temp_C))+
  geom_histogram()
temp_hist_sum

#Fall temperature histogram
temp_hist_fall <- na_data %>% 
  filter(Season == "Fall") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Temp_C))+
  geom_histogram()
temp_hist_fall 

#Winter temperature histogram
temp_hist_wint <- na_data %>% 
  filter(Season == "Winter") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Temp_C))+
  geom_histogram()
temp_hist_wint 


# Final Seasons Temperature Graph: 
seasons_temp_hist <- na_data %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Temp_C, fill = Season))+
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1, alpha = 0.5, position = "identity")
seasons_temp_hist



```
